{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3130040,"name":"Christopher149","username":"Christopher149","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/838e76/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-19T22:18:50.206Z","cooked":"

We’d like to avoid tank drive this year but have been having some code trouble with both our mecanum and our swerve drives (a future post I plan to make) which is making it tricky to decide on drivetrain. Code we’re using for the mecanum is based on allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/mecanumcontrollercommand at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub. We’ve had previous success with the RamseteCommand with tank drive.

Teleop works fine but auto just jerks forward a back a couple inches a couple times before stopping. We did fix what looks like a mistake in parameter order in getCurrentWheelSpeeds() and getCurrentWheelDistances(), and another issue that I see got a fix in the example 16 hours ago.

Code: GitHub - SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2023MecanumTest: 2023 test of mecanum code
Robot is NEOs with Spark MAXes over CAN, with 8" AM mecanum wheels in Toughbox Micro gearboxes, I think 12.75:1, ADIS16470 IMU board

On a probably unrelated note, we can’t seem to get sysid to work right with this chassis. I don’t think I’ve tried every input combination, but I’ve only ever gotten the robot to turn doing the quasistatic forward test, but some of my attempts cause it to think I’ve mismatched the mechanism type when I only ever ask for “drivetrain”.

I am not able to parse the code (it links fine, but my brain is not able to parse code yet). However, I wonder if the two issues are related.

If you are spinning in quasistatic forward, my guess is the spark max controllers are not set right. Either they are listed wrong FR,FL,RR,RL assignments may actually be RL controller, FL controller, etc. Or, a motor (or four) is inverted, or a combination.

This issue is easy to control for with teleoo, you just invert the axis.

When the controller takes over, the algorithm does not work because the control is disconnected from the feedback (sort of). We have had this happen before.
